channel.title: Strong Medicine
channel.description:
Educational videos on a variety of medical topics, produced by Eric Strong - a clinical assistant professor of medicine at Stanford University, and a practicing hospitalist.
I try to answer as many questions as I can in the comments, but unfortunately, the current volume prevents me from guaranteeing everyone a timely response. If you see that someone else's question is currently unanswered, and you feel relatively confident of the answer, please share your knowledge!
Show your support by subscribing, and by liking and sharing those videos you've found helpful.
I cannot dispense specific medical advice on here about an individual's medical problems. It's always best to consult a health care professional in person for any symptom or physical ailment.
The occasional mention of my institution is only to acknowledge my academic affiliation, and implies neither intellectual property ownership nor endorsement of this material by Stanford.

item.title: An Approach to Acute Abdominal Pain
item.description:
An overview of the etiologies and diagnostic evaluation of acute abdominal pain, including a discussion of the surgical abdomen.
Also included are the illness scripts for gastroenteritis, peptic ulcer disease, small bowel obstruction, appendicitis, pancreatitis, biliary colic, cholecystitis, cholangitis, and acute hepatitis.

item.title: Community Acquired Pneumonia
item.description:
A review of the clinical presentation (symptoms and exam findings), microbiology, prognostication, and treatment of community acquired pneumonia - including incorporation of the long-awaited 2019 IDSA/ATS CAP guidelines.
This is a continuation of Strong Medicine's ongoing Intern Crash Course series.
2019 IDSA/ATS CAP Guidelines: https://www.atsjournals.org/doi/full/10.1164/rccm.201908-1581ST
Strong Medicine's video on identifying and classifying pneumonia based on chest X-ray: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fiGgpY2GXsk

item.title: How to Pronounce a Death
item.description: An overview of the steps necessary to pronounce the death of a hospitalized patient, including components of the pronouncement exam (a.k.a. death exam) and the death note.

item.title: How To Run A Family Meeting
item.description: An overview for interns, as well as medical/nursing/PA students, on how to run a family meeting in the hospital.

item.title: 10 Tips On How To Be An Effective Intern: Rounds
item.description: 10 quick pearls on how to rock your hospital rounds as an intern.

item.title: Alcohol Withdrawal
item.description:
An overview of the classification and treatment of alcohol withdrawal, including discussion of withdrawal seizures, delirium tremens (DT), CIWA scores, and "benzo-sparing" protocols.
Thumbnail incorporated an image of whiskey bottle and glass (bottle-glass-whiskey_1308-24939), provided by user brgfx, and downloaded from www.freepik.com in July 2019.

item.title: 10 Tips On How To Be An Effective Intern: The Physical Exam
item.description:
A list of 10 clinical pearls about the physical exam that will help you be a more effective intern, and deliver better patient care.
I know that some of these (e.g. tailor your exam to why the patient is in the hospital, don't shortchange exams on patients with disabilities) seem obvious, but I see these concepts forgotten or ignored all of the time. If I had a dime for every progress note whose exam was verbatim: "Chest - CTAB; Heart - RRR, nl S1 S2, no m/r/g; Abd - Soft, NT, ND, normal BS; Extremities - No c/c/e; Neuro - AAOx3, non-focal" irrespective of whether the patient was admitted for a stroke, arrhythmia, or bowel perforation...
A few references:
The lack of hypotension in the majority of patients with pericardial tamponade: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/206803
The uselessness of auscultation of bowel sounds: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4566372/ https://blogs.jwatch.org/frontlines-clinical-medicine/2017/03/01/listening-bowel-sounds-outdated-practice/
Tips and exam strategies for patients with physical or cognitive disabilities: https://wordpress.uchospitals.edu/transitioncare/files/2012/05/Kalichman.ExamStrategies.pdf https://www.mountsinai.org/about/diversity/disabilities/physical-sensory-disabilities
A wonderful, general resource for learning more about the physical exam: https://stanfordmedicine25.stanford.edu/
The video thumbnail incorporated a picture of a reflex hammer provided by user MacSeagull under CC BY SA 4.0 and downloaded from Wikimedia Commons July 2019.

item.title: Space Medicine
item.description:
A discussion of human physiology in space, focusing on the effects of microgravity and radiation.
This video is part of a multichannel collaboration from WeCreateEdu on the theme of space to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 mission.
Please see our complete video playlist here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlt1h57yoMAGlmwJ7FaF3PzOR81qSUXj2&jct=2KhJBcvjDtdjV3aU3B9IWAZlOBO3lg&disable_polymer=1
All images, videos, and animations provided by NASA, except as noted:
Opening sequence of Earth from Space: “Earth From Space Animation” provided royalty-free by jonaslisting. Downloaded from videvo.net, July 2019.
The internal ear: “Internal Ear Anatomy” provided by BruceBlaus under CC BY 3.0. Downloaded from Wikimedia Commons, July 2019.
Blue anatomic figures: Purchased with applicable rights from Shutterstock.com.
Moon: “FullMoon2010” provided by Gregory H. Revera under CC BY SA 3.0. Downloaded from Wikimedia Commons, July 2019.
Mars: “ORIRIS“ provided by the European Space Agency under CC BY SA 3.0 IGO. Downloaded from Wikimedia Commons, July 2019.
Open and closing music: “Bathed in the Light – Calming” by Kevin MacLeod, provided under CC BY 4.0. Downloaded from YouTube, July 2019.
All other music provided without required attribution and downloaded from YouTube, July 2019.

item.title: Heart Failure (Acute Decompensated Heart Failure)
item.description:
An overview of the etiologies, classification (wet vs. dry / warm vs. cold), and treatment of acute decompensated heart failure. (I'm sorry, but this is the one video of the Intern Crash Course series that's going to be over 10 minutes - heart failure is just too large a topic to shorten that much!)
For additional reading:
Antohi EL, et al. Therapeutic Advances in the Management of Acute Decompensated Heart Failure. Am J Ther; 2019 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30839371)
Kurmani S, et al. Acute Heart Failure: Definition, Classification and Epidemiology. Curr Heart Fail Rep; 2017 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28785969)
Evaluation and Management of Patients with Acute Decompensated Heart Failure. Journal of Cardiac Failure; 2010 (https://www.hfsa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/HFSA-2010-HF-Guidelines-Section-12.pdf)
Heart image used in thumbnail courtesy of Patrick Lynch. Provided under CC BY 2.5. Downloaded from Wikimedia Commons July 2019.

item.title: 12 Words To Never Say In The Hospital
item.description: The words we use during patient care has an impact on our attitudes and empathy. Some innocuous (and some not so innocuous) words commonly used by doctors can have a negative impact on how we view our patients.

item.title: 10 Tips On How To Be An Effective Intern: Meds
item.description:
A list of 10 clinical pearls about medications that will help you be a more effective intern, and help you deliver better patient care.
A few references:
Unnecessary use of IV hydralazine for asymptomatic hypertension: https://www.journalofhospitalmedicine.com/jhospmed/article/176615/hospital-medicine/acute-treatment-hypertensive-urgency
Atenolol is a poor choice for an antihypertensive: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28760243 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15530629 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28107561
Overuse of antipsychotics in delirium: https://www.journalofhospitalmedicine.com/jhospmed/article/195967/hospital-medicine/things-we-do-no-reason-use-antipsychotic-medications?channel=27621
Dangers of tramadol: https://emcrit.org/toxhound/tramadont/
Basics of inpatient diabetes management (from Strong Medicine): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tzn4jGEL87I

item.title: How To Call A Consult
item.description: An overview of how to call an inpatient consult as a medicine intern, resident, or student - complete with demo.

item.title: COPD Exacerbations
item.description:
A quick overview of the diagnosis and treatment of COPD exacerbations, aimed at medicine interns and clinical students.
For more information about COPD, please check out: copdgold.org
More videos from Strong Medicine on COPD and asthma: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VCXVmHJ8a-U&list=PLYojB5NEEakWxqnCBgl5_5rGXEP7VYGVT
Videos from Strong Medicine on PFT interpretation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6TApeMJ-rkc&list=PLYojB5NEEakWFguxxf0QMU-akB_us5M9R

item.title: 10 Tips On How To Be An Effective Intern: Bedside Care
item.description: Clinical pearls for how to be an effective intern, with a focus on bedside care.

item.title: Intern Crash Course: An Introduction
item.description: An introduction to Strong Medicine's new series, Intern Crash Course, where I'll be discussing the most important information and skills that a new intern needs to know in order to succeed on the wards.

item.title: Anemia: Lesson 5 - An Approach to Diagnosis
item.description: An approach to diagnosing anemia, applying knowledge of the diagnostic frameworks, iron panel, hemolysis labs, and blood smear.

item.title: Anemia: Lesson 4 - Clues from the blood smear
item.description: A review of some common abnormalities seen on a blood smear of patients presenting with anemia: hypochromia, schistocytes, microspherocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils, bite cells, sickle cells, target cells, basophilic stippling, etc...

item.title: Anemia: Lesson 3 - Hemolysis
item.description: An overview of hemolysis, including a discussion of its many etiologies and how to diagnose it, as well as the direct Coombs test (a.k.a. direct agglutination test).

item.title: Anemia: Lesson 2 - Interpreting the Iron Panel
item.description: An overview of the iron panel: what tests are included, what they are measuring, and how to interpret the results.

item.title: Anemia: Lesson 1 - Diagnostic Frameworks
item.description: A discussion on the definition, symptoms/signs, and diagnostic frameworks (a.k.a. diagnostic schema) for anemia. Both the morphological (i.e. microcytic vs. normocytic vs. macrocytic) and kinetic (i.e. hypoproliferative vs. hyperproliferative) frameworks are covered, including their limitations.

item.title: How to Interpret RBC Indices (e.g. hemoglobin vs. hematocrit, MCV, RDW)
item.description: An overview of the RBC indices of a complete blood count (CBC), and how to interpret them. Covered tests include hemoglobin, hematocrit, MCV, MCH, MCHC, and RDW.

item.title: Normal RBC Physiology (Including erythropoiesis)
item.description:
An overview of the structure, function, formation/maturation (i.e. erythropoiesis), and removal of red blood cells, including the distinction between reticulocytes and mature erythrocytes.
A related discussion of the structure and function of hemoglobin: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UDwyurNaiZ0&t=421s

item.title: Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) in a Nutshell
item.description: An overview of ILD (also known as diffuse parenchymal lung diseases), including definition, classification, etiologies, and diagnostic evaluation (e.g. CT and PFT findings).

item.title: An Approach to Chronic Diarrhea
item.description: A discussion of the definition, etiologies, and evaluation of chronic diarrhea.

item.title: AMA (ask me anything) to celebrate 250k subs
item.description:
I answer your questions about my thoughts and experiences in medicine, and some other stuff too.
The original AMA announcement where questions were posted: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=--Lio9UdQDM
For those questions I didn't answer in this video, I will post answers in response to the original comments over the next several weeks.
Some videos I refer to in the AMA... 10 Fixable Problems in Medical Education: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z070XAGDvOU How To Study in Med School: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f06a8aHJK30 How to Succeed in Your Medicine Clerkship: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZzAL09iR5_c
Physicians to consider following on Twitter (yes, an IM bias): Tony Breu – Hospitalist (@tony_breu) Vinay Prasad – Oncologist (@VPrasadMDMPH) Reza Manesh – Internist (@DxRxEdu) Lakshman Swamy – Pulm/CC fellow (@laxswamy) Vinny Arora – Hospitalist (@FutureDocs) Seth Trueger – Emergency medicine (@MDaware) Venk Murthy – Cardiac imaging (@venkmurthy) Avital O’Glasser – Hospitalist (@aoglasser) Joel Topf – Nephrologist (@kidney_boy) Kenny Lin – Family physician (@kennylinafp) Dr. Glaucomflecken – Ophthalmologist (@DGlaucomflecken) John Mandrola – Electrophysiologist (@drjohnm) Charlie Wray – Hospitalist (@WrayCharles) Jessica Otte – Family physician (@LessIsMoreMed) Adam Cifu – Internist (@adamcifu) Aaron Carroll – Health policy (@aaroncarroll) Robert Centor – Internist (@medrants)

item.title: Blood Types - An Introduction to the ABO and Rh Systems
item.description: An introduction to the biology and genetics of the blood types, focusing on the ABO and Rh systems. Also included is a brief history of blood transfusions, and an overview of hemolytic transfusion reactions and hemolytic disease of the newborn.

item.title: AMA Announcement
item.description:
To celebrate crossing 250k subscribers soon, I'm having my first AMA ("ask me anything") here on YouTube. Post any questions (medicine, medical education, YouTube videos, whatever), and I'll post a video with my responses once I hit the magic number.
(I know it's an AMA, but please no requests for individualized medical advice - I can't substitute for your regular doctor!)

item.title: How Do You Know If Your Doctor Is Any Good?
item.description:
A discussion of the characteristics that patients can use to differentiate good doctors from...not so good ones.
To address a couple of questions that might come up after watching this:
1. Probably the greatest and most reliable way to know if your doctor is good is if he/she is someone to whom other doctors and health care professionals refer their own family members. I don't mention that in the video because most people don't have a close personal contact in a health profession from whom they can ask this advice.
2. Regarding my assertion that the prestige of med school and training program is not predictive of the quality of *routine* care of patients, that's largely based on my personal experience (and the experience of family members and friends who have told me about their experiences with various doctors of different training pedigrees). I should have pointed out in the video that there *may* be a threshold effect whereby it doesn't matter until one reaches the schools that are particularly poorly regarded. For better or worse, I rarely interact with docs from these schools in my clinical practice, and to the best of my knowledge, there is no data that looks at such a question.
3. I don't mention whether the physician is affiliated with a major academic center, but this is similar as the prestige of a physician's training. It doesn't matter for routine care, but if a patient's condition was either unusually mysterious, or unusually complex, it's best to see doctors at a university-affiliated academic medical center.
4. In retrospect, I realize that I didn't discuss MD vs. DO. But if I had, it would only be to say that it doesn't matter, as long as the DO doesn't practice osteopathic manipulation (a.k.a. OMT). Although DO schools teach OMT, many practicing DOs recognize it as pseudoscientific nonsense.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 10 - Von Willebrand Disease and Qualitative Platelet Disorders
item.description: An overview of the pathogenesis, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment of inherited von Willebrand Disease, acquired von Willebrand syndrome, and qualitative platelet disorders (including uremic platelet dysfunction).

item.title: An Approach to Hematuria
item.description: A discussion of the definition, etiologies, and diagnostic work-up of hematuria (i.e. blood in the urine), including an assessment for bladder cancer.

item.title: An Approach to GI Bleeding (Melena, Hematemesis, Hematochezia)
item.description: A discussion of the etiologies and work-up of GI bleeding, as well as the difference between melena, hematemesis, and hematochezia.

item.title: An Approach to Jaundice
item.description:
A description of the etiologies and diagnostic workup for patients presenting with jaundice.
Image of liver from Public Domain, downloaded from https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/liver-disease/cirrhosis/definition-facts, accessed 12/2018
Image of pancreas and bile ducts adapted from Blausen.com staff (2014). "Medical gallery of Blausen Medical 2014". WikiJournal of Medicine 1 (2). DOI:10.15347/wjm/2014.010. ISSN 2002-4436. Made available under CC BY 3.0.

item.title: My Night as an ER Patient: How My Headache May Have Prevented A Stranger's Bone Marrow Transplant
item.description:
How my headache may have prevented a woman from receiving a bone marrow transplant...I analyze 7+ hours I spent in the Stanford emergency department as a patient, touching on issues of the uncertainty of diagnostic tests, anxiety, unintended consequences, and of course, cost.
(Conflict of Interest Statement: I'm on the faculty at Stanford School of Medicine - but neither the school nor hospital had any input on the content of this video.)

item.title: The Acute Complications of Cirrhosis - An Overview
item.description: An overview of how spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, hepatic encephalopathy, esophageal varices, and the hepatorenal syndrome share common pathophysiology, and how they can trigger one another.

item.title: Hepatorenal Syndrome
item.description: An overview of the pathophysiology, triggers, diagnosis, and treatment of the hepatorenal syndrome.

item.title: Esophageal Varices and Variceal Hemorrhage
item.description: An overview of the pathogenesis of esophageal varices and the treatment of acute GI bleeds in cirrhosis. Also covered are the basic anatomy of the hepatic portal system, and TIPS (transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunts).

item.title: An Approach to Polyuria
item.description: A discussion of the definition, etiologies, work-up, and diagnosis of polyuria, including a discussion of the water deprivation test to diagnose diabetes insipidus. The distinction between polyuria, urinary frequency, and nocturia is also discussed.

item.title: An Approach to Headache
item.description:
The overview of how to approach the patient presenting with a headache, including a discussion of the various etiologies, a comparison of tension and migraine headaches, and a review of the red flags that should trigger neuroimaging.
Thanks to Dr. Veronica Santini and some folks on Twitter for providing feedback on specific sections!

item.title: Trailer for Strong Medicine
item.description:
An Introduction to Strong Medicine - A free, open-access resource for medical professionals and those in training.
Aside from very small advertising revenue generated from this YouTube channel, I have no other financial conflicts of interest. I receive no money or other support from the pharmaceutical and medical device industries.

item.title: An Approach to Peripheral Edema
item.description: A review of how to approach peripheral edema, including the distinction between pitting vs. non-pitting, acute vs. chronic, and symmetric vs. asymmetric edema. I also discuss how the etiologies of edema can be categorized based on the Starling Equation.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 9 - Thrombocytosis
item.description: An overview of thrombocytosis, including etiologies and a focused discussion on essential thrombocythemia and polycythemia vera.

item.title: Hepatic Encephalopathy
item.description:
An overview of one of the more common complications of cirrhosis, including its pathophysiology (and relationship to ammonia), risk factors, clinical presentation (including asterixis), diagnosis, and treatment.
EDIT: I know the closing refers to 2 as-of-yet not uploaded videos (hepatorenal syndrome, upper GI bleeds in cirrhosis) - they will be posted within the next 2 weeks.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 8 - Thrombocytopenia
item.description: An overview of thrombocytopenia, with a specific focus on DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura), and HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia). Platelet transfusion thresholds are also discussed.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 7 - Prothrombotic Medications
item.description: An overview of the more common prothrombotic medications, including desmopressin (ddAVP), recombinant factor VII (NovoSeven), emicizumab, aminocaproic acid (Amicar), and tranexamic acid (Lysteda).

item.title: What is a Hospitalist?
item.description:
At the request of some folks on the medicalschool subreddit, here's my summary of what a hospitalist does. I answer 4 primary questions: 1. What is a hospitalist? 2. How does one become a hospitalist? 3. What are some common myths about hospitalists? 4. What are the pros and cons of being a hospitalist?
For anyone interested, here's a non-medical project that I spent the summer working on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sceURVXaQ_A

item.title: Lessons Learned From My Dad's Illness and Death
item.description:
In brief: - It's never too early to start preparing when a loved one is given a terminal diagnosis. - Falls can be catastrophic. - The decision to forgo SNF placement in favor of staying at home for as long as possible is a delicate one which should be approached with as much informed consent as a surgery. - Let terminally ill patients eat whatever they want. - Think twice before admitting elderly, delirium-prone patients to the hospital for "observation". - All interventions have risk of harm. If a treatment is not likely to help, don't offer it. - Hospice is sometimes the only way to stop a person from getting repeatedly admitted to the hospital, irrespective of their goals of care. - Be sure to communicate with your patients' families regularly, even if they haven't been calling (because maybe they have been, and you just haven't been getting their messages). - Don't use Ativan or Dilaudid in patients with dementia. Just don't. - A person will have a much more meaningful experience visiting a terminally ill loved one earlier in the their course of illness rather than showing up just at the end.
EDIT: Thank you to everyone for the kind words!

item.title: An Approach to Chronic Dyspnea
item.description: A discussion of the etiologies and work-up of chronic dyspnea.

item.title: An Approach to Hemoptysis
item.description: An overview of the etiologies and appropriate work-up for a patient presenting with hemoptysis (i.e. coughing up blood).

item.title: An Approach to Palpitations
item.description:
An overview of the causes of palpitations, and the approach to diagnosis.
For more information on how to distinguish various arrhythmias from one another on ECG, or for info on congenital arrhythmogenic disorders, please check out my video series on ECG interpretation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W5cw1cAxXIs&list=PLYojB5NEEakXhL1WoDvNPm1cG57pjE0d7

item.title: An Approach to Cough
item.description: An overview of a diagnostic framework and algorithm for approaching a patient who presents with either acute or chronic cough. Etiologies discussed include upper airway cough syndrome, cough-variant asthma, and laryngopharyngeal reflux, among many others. I also discuss indications for a chest X-ray in a patient presenting with cough.

item.title: 10 Fixable Problems In US Medical Education
item.description:
For the record, this list is not only based on my direct personal experiences at my current and former institutions, but also based on countless conversations with students and faculty at other institutions, discussions at meetings/conferences, and chatter on social media (thanks for the insights /r/medicalschool!). None of these criticisms should be inferred to be directed at any specific individual, school, or program.
"Dishonorable" mentions to poor implementation of problem-based learning, poor use of PowerPoint, poorly written tests, excessive focus on basic science at the expense of clinical science, having content experts each teach individual lectures within a course instead of a single expert teacher teaching the whole course, inadequate attention given to evidence-based medicine (i.e. how to look-up, appraise, and apply clinical evidence), uselessness of Step 2 CS, and inadequate consideration given to student input in their own education.
A problem which unfortunately doesn't look to me to be fixable is our current time-based training, rather than competency-based training. In other words, medical school and residency are a fixed number of years in duration, after which all but the absolute lowest performers are graduated. Since the primary goal of medical training is to ensure that doctors are competent clinicians, it would be more logical for trainees to graduate at the point when they meet a prespecified list of milestones, irrespective of how long or short it takes to achieve that. But the logistical challenges to implementing this seem insurmountable.
Additional info on problems related to physicians seeking help for mental health and/or substance abuse: https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/849772

item.title: An Approach to Acute Dyspnea
item.description: An overview of the diagnostic approach to the acute onset of shortness of breath.

item.title: An Approach to Shock
item.description: An overview of the diagnostic approach to shock, including a description of how to distinguish between hypovolemic, distributive (e.g. sepsis), cardiogenic, and obstructive subtypes.

item.title: An Approach to Chest Pain
item.description: A overview of the diagnostic approach to a patient with acute chest pain, focusing on the life-threatening etiologies of acute coronary syndrome (i.e. an acute MI), pulmonary embolism, aortic dissection, and pneumothorax.

item.title: An Approach to Syncope
item.description: An overview of the diagnostic approach to syncope, including comparison between reflex (i.e. vasovagal), cardiogenic, and orthostatic etiologies. A comparison between syncope, seizure, and other syncope mimics is also discussed.

item.title: Introduction to the Approach to Symptoms Video Series
item.description: A brief description of the learning objectives, format, and intended audience for this series on the diagnostic approach to common symptoms.

item.title: Exciting Announcement from Strong Medicine
item.description: Strong Medicine is collaborating with others at Stanford to create a robust, free, open-access clinical reasoning curriculum. But we need your input!

item.title: Acute Kidney Injury (Part 3/3 - Treatment and Complications)
item.description: The conclusion of this short series on AKI. Covered topics include the treatment of various forms of AKI, complications (e.g. volume overload, hyperkalemia, hypertension, metabolic acidosis, drug toxicity, and uremia), and an introduction to dialysis.

item.title: The Diversity of Sex, Gender, and Sexual Orientation
item.description:
An overview of sex, gender, and sexual orientation. Covered terminology and concepts include gender identity vs. gender expression; intersex, transgender, non-binary, and genderfluid individuals; straight vs. gay/lesbian vs. bisexual vs. pansexual vs. asexual; and the differences between sexual attraction, sexual behavior, romantic attraction, and sexual identity.
Health Across the Gender Spectrum: https://www.coursera.org/learn/health-gender-spectrum
National LGBT Health Education Center (Fenway Institute): https://www.lgbthealtheducation.org/
UCSF Center of Excellence for Transgender Health: http://transhealth.ucsf.edu/

item.title: Acute Kidney Injury (Part 2/3 - Diagnostic Evaluation)
item.description: A review of the labs and other data that are used to identify the etiology of AKI, including BUN:Cr ratio, FENa, FEurea, urinalysis, post-void residual (PVR), and assessment of urine output.

item.title: Acute Kidney Injury (Part 1/3 - Definitions and Etiologies)
item.description: An overview of the definition of AKI and its common etiologies, including a description of the prerenal-intrarenal-postrenal paradigm. The terms uremia and azotemia are also discussed.

item.title: Shock: Lesson 5 - Pressors
item.description: A discussion of the physiology, pharmacology, and clinical use of vasopressors and inotropes, including phenylephrine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine, and dobutamine (among others).

item.title: How to Appraise a Clinical Trial - Part 3
item.description:
The final part of an overview of how to read and critically evaluate a clinical trial, prior to applying the information to your patient. Included is a discussion of the surrogate and composite endpoints, systematic biases in research, validity, and the difference between clinical and statistical significance.
For a printable summary of this video series, see the pdf located here: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B9SDUwepGWeUTmtscnJSSjR5OE0?pageId=113257053107946991725

item.title: Antiarrhytmics (Lesson 7 - How to Choose the Right Med and Classic Pitfalls)
item.description: A discussion of how to choose the right antiarrhythmic to rate control and pharmacologically cardiovert atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter, as well as converting and prevention of ventricular tachycardia. An overall summary of this series is also presented.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 6 - Digoxin, Adenosine, Atropine, Isoproterenol, and Ivabradine)
item.description: An overview of the so-called unclassifiable antiarrhythmics, including their mechanism of action, indications, and side effects.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 5 - Calcium Channel Blockers)
item.description: An overview of the mechanism, indications, and side effects of calcium channel blockers.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 4 - Potassium Channel Blockers)
item.description: Mechanism, indications, and side effects of potassium channel blockers, including a discussion of torsades de pointes, as well as use dependence vs. reverse use dependence.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 3 - Beta Blockers)
item.description: A review of beta blockers, including their mechanism of action, indications, and side effects.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 2 - Sodium Channel Blockers)
item.description: A review of class I antiarrhythmics - the sodium channel blockers (e.g. quinidine, procainamide, lidocaine, mexiletine, flecainide, and propafenone). Mechanisms, indications, and side effects are all discussed.

item.title: Antiarrhythmics (Lesson 1 - An Introduction)
item.description:
An introduction to antiarrhythmics, including a description of the Singh-Vaughan Williams classification system, and a review of the cardiac action potential.
For more discussion about action potential, check out this excellent video from Bozeman Science (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HYLyhXRp298)

item.title: How to Apply Evidence to a Patient (Shared Decision Making)
item.description:
A description of how to determine the applicability of clinical research to an individual patient, as well as how to use shared decision making to incorporate a patient's specific values in that application.
Additional Resources to Learn More:
How to decide on the applicability of clinical trial results to your patient. JAMA 1998 279:545-9. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/0009480367)
How to use an article about therapy or prevention. What were the results and will they help me in caring for my patients? JAMA 1994 271:59-63. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8258890)
Integrating research evidence with the care of the individual patient. JAMA 2000 283:2829-36 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10838653)
Prime Time for Shared Decision Making. JAMA 2017 317:1309-10. (http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/2614196)
All about the NNT (http://www.thennt.com/)
Dr. Cates' personal EBM website (http://www.nntonline.net/visualrx/cates_plot/)
Explaining risks: turning numerical data into meaningful pictures. BMJ 2002 324:827-30. (http://www.bmj.com/content/324/7341/827.1)

item.title: How to Appraise a Clinical Trial - Part 2
item.description:
An overview of how to read and critically evaluate a clinical trial, prior to applying the information to your patient. Included is a discussion of the importance of randomization, controls, blinding, allocation concealment, proper sample size, and more.
For a printable summary of this series on appraising a clinical trial, see the relevant pdf located here: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B9SDUwepGWeUTmtscnJSSjR5OE0?pageId=113257053107946991725

item.title: How to Appraise a Clinical Trial - Part 1
item.description: An overview of how to read and critically evaluate a clinical trial, prior to applying the information to your patient. Included is a discussion of the importance of randomization, controls, blinding, allocation concealment, proper sample size, and more.

item.title: Most Published Medical Research is Wrong
item.description:
A discussion of how systematic bias, publication bias, random error (a.k.a. statistically predictable error), and conflicts of interest result in most published research being wrong. Recommendations of how to improve the problem are also discussed.
Ending Medical Reversal (https://www.amazon.com/Ending-Medical-Reversal-Improving-Outcomes/dp/1421417723)
Why Most Published Research Findings Are False (http://robotics.cs.tamu.edu/RSS2015NegativeResults/pmed.0020124.pdf)
Is Everything We Eat Associated With Cancer? (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23193004)
Translation of highly promising basic science research into clinical applications (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12731504)
Estimating the reproducibility of psychological science (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26315443)
A Decade of Reversal: An Analysis of 146 Contradicted Medical Practices (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23871230)
Selective Publication of Antidepressant Trials and Its Influence on Apparent Efficacy (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18199864)
John Oliver / Last Week Tonight on Scientific Studies and p hacking (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Rnq1NpHdmw)
Derek Muller/ Veritasium on whether most published research is wrong (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=42QuXLucH3Q)
Seinfeld's Junior Mint episode (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M29A6rZpKqk)

item.title: An Introduction to Evidence Based Medicine
item.description: An intro to EBM, including a discussion of the different types of studies, the hierarchy of evidence, and the role of EBM in broader clinical practice.

item.title: Advanced EKGs - Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome
item.description: An overview of WPW syndrome, including pathophysiology, EKG characteristics, and associated arrhythmias (e.g. AVRT). How to localize the accessory pathway is also discussed.

item.title: Survey Results and Channel Update
item.description:
The results of last week's survey for new Strong Medicine topics and other suggestions.
Free lecture notes for Strong Medicine here: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B9SDUwepGWeUTmtscnJSSjR5OE0&usp=sharing

item.title: How to Study in Medical School
item.description:
A review of successful study strategies in med school, including retrieval practice (testing effect), spaced repetition, and varied practice. I also discuss common learning myths, including learning styles. And I end with a discussion of popular study resources for med students, including Pathoma, First Aid, Picmonic, SketchyMedical, Anki, Firecracker, Osmosis, Najeeb, and more...
In direct response to some comments, I would like to emphasize that I'm not asserting "Sketchy" doesn't work - I'm just saying that the study technique it uses is unproven and is novel enough to not yet have established a conventional wisdom about it among learning scientists. Also, regarding First Aid, I appreciate that Step 1 is perceived to test the long lists of unconnected esoteric facts that First Aid is great for, however, I also see students use First Aid as a primary resource for their courses, which I think has major drawbacks.
Selected references include:
Make It Stick - The single best layperson guide to learning theory (https://www.amazon.com/Make-Stick-Science-Successful-Learning/dp/0674729013/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8)
Learning Scientists Blog - Another great resource for all things related to the science of learning. (http://www.learningscientists.org/blog/)
"Paradoxes of learning and memory" - Free book chapter outlining some successful study strategies, with discussion of how they can be counterintuitive. (http://psych.wustl.edu/memory/Roddy%20article%20PDF's/Butler%20&%20Roediger%20(2011).pdf)
"The Learning Styles Myth is Thriving in Higher Education" (http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01908/full)
"Metacognition and the spacing effect: the role of repetition, feedback, and instruction on judgments of learning for massed and spaced rehearsal" - Also touches on our inability to accurately judge successful learning (http://castel.psych.ucla.edu/papers/Logan%20JOL%20Spacing%20ML.pdf)
"The effect of selected 'desirable difficulties' on the ability to recall anatomy information" - Also touches on retrieval practice and the testing effect (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25227209)
"The Picmonic(®) Learning System: enhancing memory retention of medical sciences, using an audiovisual mnemonic Web-based learning platform." - Peer reviewed paper written by founders of Picmonic (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24868180)
Links to Resources:
Anki (http://www.ankisrs.net) Firecracker (http://www.firecracker.me) Osmosis (http://www.osmosis.org) UWorld (https://www.uworld.com/) Kaplan Qbank (https://www.kaptest.com/medical-prep/usmle/usmle-prep-course/step-1-qbank) USMLE-Rx (https://www.usmle-rx.com/) SketchyMedical (https://www.sketchymedical.com/) Picmonic (http://www.picmonic.com/) Pathoma (http://www.pathoma.com/) First Aid for Step 1 (https://www.amazon.com/First-Aid-Usmle-Step-2016/dp/1259587371) Dr. Najeeb (https://www.drnajeeblectures.com/) The Noted Anatomist (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCe9lb3da4XAnN7v3ciTyquQ) Armando Hasudungan (http://armandoh.org/)

item.title: Advanced EKGs - Sudden Cardiac Death (Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, ARVD, Brugada syndrome, and CPVT)
item.description: A discussion of 4 miscellaneous inherited arrhythmogenic syndromes, including clinical manifestations and genetics, in addition to EKG findings.

item.title: How to Measure Blood Pressure
item.description: An overview of blood pressure: What is it, how to measure it, and why is it important?

item.title: Advanced EKGs - The QT Interval and Long QT Syndrome
item.description: An overview of the many nuances involved in measuring the QT interval, along with a review of the etiologies of a long QT interval and the features of the potentially fatal arrhythmia torsades de pointes.

item.title: Tips for New Docs
item.description: 10 tips for new medical school graduates who are starting residency. (applicable to med students and attending physicians as well!)

item.title: Syncope
item.description:
A review of the definition, etiology, and cost-effective work-up of syncope (e.g. fainting or passing out)

item.title: Free Lecture Notes and Sample Book Chapters from Strong Medicine
item.description:
Follow the link to Google Drive below in order to access free notes for the videos on Strong Medicine, as well as 2 sample chapters from (hopefully) upcoming books: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B9SDUwepGWeUTmtscnJSSjR5OE0

item.title: Pradaxa and Xarelto: A Case Study in Evidence Based Medicine
item.description:
A discussion of the controversies surrounding the RE-LY and ROCKET-AF trials, which led to the initial FDA approvals of dabigatran (Pradaxa) and rivaroxaban (Xarelto) respectively.
Please note that in the years since this video was posted, additional studies have been published which support the use of these drugs. I leave the video up because the issues discussed are still relevant. However, if you are a layperson, please do NOT stop taking your Xarelto or Pradaxa just because you watched this video. Instead, discuss your concerns with your physician. There are more than one alternative anticoagulant out there.
I declare that I have no conflicts of interest, and receive no compensation from the pharmaceutical or device industries.
Original RE-LY Trial: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19717844
Original ROCKET-AF Trial: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21830957
BMJ Criticisms of Dabigatran RE-LY: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25056265 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25055831 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25055829
BMJ Criticism of ROCKET-AF and Rivaroxaban: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26843102
Recent media coverage of dabigatran and RE-LY: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/federal-eye/wp/2015/10/15/fda-was-lax-and-kowtowed-to-drugmaker-in-review-of-controversial-blood-thinner-watchdog-says/ http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/08/business/new-emails-in-pradaxa-case-show-concern-over-profit.html http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/06/business/study-of-blood-clot-drug-pradaxa-unnerved-its-maker-documents-suggest.html
Recent media coverage of rivaroxaban and ROCKET-AF: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/23/business/fda-asks-if-faulty-blood-monitor-tainted-xarelto-approval.html?_r=0 http://www.cbsnews.com/news/did-heart-drug-makers-withhold-data-from-medical-journal/

item.title: What is the Best Way to Teach Science?
item.description:
A short commentary on the best approach educators can take when teaching science. This was inspired by BrainCraft's video on the same topic here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6F3FmowlmpM
Title images include: Leaning Tower of Pisa: Stylized rendering Double Slit Experiment: By user Stannered, downloaded from Wikimedia Commons, and provided under CC BY-SA 3.0 Michelson-Morley Experiment: By user Bighead, downloaded from Wikimedia Commons, and provided under CC BY-SA 3.0

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 6 - Anticoagulation and Thrombolytics
item.description: An overview of the indications, mechanisms, pharmacology, and side effects of anticoagulants and thrombolytics (including warfarin/Coumadin, the various forms of heparin, and the NOACs/DOACs).

item.title: Asthma and COPD: Acute Exacerbations
item.description: How to identify and treat acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD. Included is a discussion of antibiotics, the use of peak flow meters, possible worsening of hypercapnia with oxygen therapy, and the association between COPD and pulmonary embolisms.

item.title: Asthma and COPD: Stable Disease - Diagnosis and Management
item.description: An overview of how asthma and COPD are diagnosed, staged, and treated. Discussion of pharmacology, including indications for certain drugs, is included.

item.title: Social Media in Medical Education
item.description: A grand overview of the role of social media in contemporary medical education, including tips for effective incorporation of social media tools and apps into curricula, and a discussion of social media's limitations. Material presented here is taken from a Grand Rounds I originally presented to the internal medicine department at Highland Hospital.

item.title: Physiology of Insulin and Glucagon
item.description: A description of the competing roles of insulin and glycogen, including their effects on glucose homeostasis, and other metabolic hormones (e.g. GLP1, GIP, cortisol, growth hormone, etc...). Pancreatic histology and insulin synthesis are also briefly discussed.

item.title: What is a normal heart rate?
item.description:
Deconstructing the myth that the normal range for the resting heart rate is 60-100.
REFERENCES
Maximum predicted HR: Robergs R, Landwehr R. The surprising history of the "HRmax = 200-age" equation. Journal of Exercise Physiology online. 2002; 5:1-10. https://www.asep.org/asep/asep/Robergs2.pdf
Fetal HR: DuBose TJ. Embryonic heart rates. Fertil Steril. 2009; 92:e57. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19748085
Evidence for normal heart rate range: Mason JW, et al. Electrocardiographic reference ranges derived from 79,743 ambulatory subjects. J Electrocardiol. 2007; 40:228-34. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17276451
Survey of cardiologists about defining normal sinus rhythm: Spodick DH. Survey of selected cardiologists for an operational definition of normal sinus heart rate. Am J Cardiol. 1993; 72:487-8. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8352202
History of "normal sinus rhythm": Dolgin M. Normal sinus rhythm. Am J Cardiol. 1993; 71:496-7. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8430659
Kossmann CE. The normal electrocardiogram. Circulation. 1953;920-36. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/13106913
Spodick DH. Is there such a thing as normal sinus rate? Br Heart J. 1993;486-7. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8260287
HR and mortality following a myocardial infarction: Hjalmarson A, et al. Influence of heart rate on mortality after acute myocardial infarction. Am J Cardiol. 1990;65:547-53. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1968702
HR and mortality among all adults: Aladin A, et al. Relation of resting heart rate to risk for all-cause mortality by gender after considering exercise capacity (the Henry Ford exercise testing project). Am J Cardiol. 2014; 114:1701-6. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25439450
General background on the topic of normal HRs: Spodick DH. Redefinition of normal sinus heart rate. Chest. 1993; 104:939-41. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8365314

item.title: Eric's Medical Lectures is becoming Strong Medicine
item.description: New name and new video coming in 2 days...

item.title: Interpretation of the Urinalysis (Part 3) - Microscopy and Summary
item.description: The final part of a short series on urinalysis interpretation, including microscopy of casts and crystals.

item.title: Interpretation of the Urinalysis (Part 2) - The Dipstick
item.description: An overview of the urine dipstick, including both how to check it as well as interpret the various possible findings.

item.title: Interpretation of the Urinalysis (Part 1) - Introduction and Inspection
item.description: An overview of the components of a UA, along with discussion of urine color and turbidity.

item.title: How to Provide Effective Inpatient Consultation
item.description: An overview of some tips on providing useful medical consultation in the hospital.

item.title: How to Succeed in Your Medicine Clerkship
item.description: 15 tips on how to succeed and thrive during your medicine clerkship.

item.title: IV Fluid Resuscitation (IVF Lesson 3 / Shock Lesson 4)
item.description: An overview of the use of IV fluids during resuscitation of patients in shock, including comparison of crystalloid vs. colloid, and NS vs. LR (and other balanced solutions).

item.title: Shock: Lesson 3 - General Treatment Principles
item.description: Overview of treatment for shock, comparing use of IV fluids and pressors between different shock subtypes.

item.title: Shock: Lesson 2 - Distinguishing Shock Types (Hypovolemic/Distributive/Cardiogenic/Obstructive)
item.description: How to use physical exam (e.g. JVP, ultrasound, passive leg raise, and extremity temp) to identify the subtype of shock. Disadvantages of PA catheters are also addressed.

item.title: Shock: Lesson 1 - Diagnosis and Classification
item.description: An overview of the manifestations of shock, and its classification (e.g. hypovolemic, cardiogenic, distributive, and obstructive)

item.title: IV Fluids: Lesson 2 - Crystalloids and Colloids
item.description: An overview of the differences in composition, properties, indications, and contraindications of various crystalloids and colloids, including normal saline, lactated ringers / Hartmann's solution, D5W, albumin, dextran, and hydroxyethyl starch.

item.title: IV Fluids: Lesson 1 - Basic Principles
item.description: Video #1 in a 4 part series on IV fluids. This video focuses on the concepts of osmosis and tonicity, body fluid compartments, and the effect of different IV fluids on the volume of those compartments.

item.title: Asthma and COPD - Pathogenesis and Pathophysiology
item.description: A review of the pathology of asthma and COPD, including the role of the immune system, along with the mechanisms behind the hypercapnia and hypoxemia of COPD, and the blue bloater vs. pink puffer pseudodichotomy.

item.title: 10 Things Every Pre-Med Should Know About Becoming a Doctor
item.description: Advice, observations, and tips about applying to medical school, surviving med school, and thriving in your subsequent career.

item.title: Asthma and COPD - An introduction
item.description: An introduction to obstructive lung disease, including definitions of asthma, chronic bronchitis, emphysema, and COPD, and a paradigm of how the diseases all relate to one another.

item.title: Channel Update
item.description:
A brief update on some recent milestones for Eric's Medical Lectures, and what to expect in the near future.
Some other favorite med ed channels (not a complete list):
Armando Hasudungan - Very visual with original artwork, focuses mostly on physiology, biochem, and immunology ftplectures - Clinically oriented topics, chalk-talk style Paul Bolin - PowerPoint based, high volume of videos, geared for USMLE step 2 and 3 preparation AnatomyZone - Extremely detailed, very visual videos to supplement med school anatomy course Student Doctor Thompson - Not strictly med ed, but gives great advice on how to thrive in med school TheEDExitVideo - Very brief, high-yield pearls about e-med, including lots of procedures

item.title: Antifungals (Fungal Infections - Lesson 4)
item.description: A review of antifungals, focusing on amphotericin B, azoles, and echinocandins. Structure, mechanism, spectrum of antifungal activity, common clinical uses, and common side effects/toxicities are all discussed.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 5 - Antiplatelet Meds (Part 2 of 2)
item.description: Part 2 of an overview on antiplatelet medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor, IIb/IIIa inhibitors, dipyridamole, and cilostazol.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 5 - Antiplatelet Meds (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: An overview of antiplatelet medications. Part 1 covers on aspirin. Part 2 covers P2Y12 inhibitors (e.g. clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor), IIb/IIIa inhibitors, dipyridamole, and cilostazol.

item.title: Mycotoxins, Allergies, and Quackery (Fungal Infections - Lesson 3)
item.description: A review of the adverse effects of fungal mycotoxins, allergic disorders triggered by fungal exposure (including ABPA), and the quackery and pseudoscience concerning fungi.

item.title: An Overview of Fungal Infections (Fungal Infections - Lesson 2)
item.description: A summary of the various types of fungal infections, including those from candida, aspergillus, cryptococcus, histoplasma, blastomyces, cocci, and dermatophytes.

item.title: Classification and Structure of Fungi (Fungal Infections - Lesson 1)
item.description: An overview of a practical classification scheme for pathological fungi, as well as a summary of their microscopic structure. Differences between yeast and mold are also discussed.

item.title: Advanced EKGs - Sinus Node Dysfunction
item.description: A summary of sinus node dysfunction, including sinus arrhythmia, SA exit block, sinus pauses, sinus arrest, sinus bradycardia, chronotropic incompetence, sick sinus syndrome, and the tachy-brady syndrome.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 4 - Tests (INR, PTT, platelets, fibrinogen, D-dimer)
item.description: A review of the measurement and interpretation of platelet count, INR, PTT, fibrinogen, d-dimer, and the mixing study.

item.title: Advanced EKGs - Miscellaneous EP Topics
item.description: A discussion of the advanced arrhythmia concepts of overdrive suppression, concealed conduction, excitable gaps, and entrainment.

item.title: Digital Stethoscope Review - Thinklabs One vs. Littmann 3200
item.description: A comparison of the Thinklabs One and Littmann 3200 digital stethoscopes, including design, performance, recording ability, software, and durability.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 3 - Coagulation Cascade and Fibrinolysis
item.description: An overview of the coagulation cascade and fibrinolysis, with emphasis on the contemporary model of coagulation (as opposed to the traditional extrinsic vs. intrinsic pathways). The role of vitamin K is also discussed.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 2 - Platelet Activation and Aggregation
item.description: Part 1 of a 2 part video on normal hemostasis, focusing on the role of the endothelium and platelets.

item.title: Hemostasis: Lesson 1 - An Introduction
item.description: A brief introduction to a course on hemostasis, which includes a broad overview of platelet activation and the coagulation cascade.

item.title: The Thyroid Exam and Physical Diagnosis of Thyroid Disease
item.description: Includes a demonstration of the standard thyroid exam, review of the etiologies of goiters, and an overview of the many physical findings of hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.

item.title: Thyroid Hormones and Thyroid Function Tests
item.description: An overview of the synthesis, regulation, and function of thyroid hormones, as well as the interpretation of thyroid function tests.

item.title: Ebola - Transmission, Symptoms, Diagnosis, and Treatment
item.description: An overview of the transmission, presentation, and treatment of Ebola, including some experimental therapies like ZMapp. Proper infection control practices are also discussed.

item.title: Ebola - An Introduction, and History from Discovery to West African Epidemic
item.description: Part 1 of 2 video series on Ebola. This part focuses on dispelling Ebola myths, as well as Ebola's history from discovery to the current West Africa epidemic.

item.title: The Diabetic Foot Exam
item.description: An overview and demonstration of the diabetic foot exam, including inspection for common deformities, evaluation of vascular supply, and screening for neuropathy.

item.title: Interpretation of LFTs (Liver Function Tests)
item.description: A review of the LFTs (AST, ALT, alk phos, GGT, albumin, INR, bilirubin), including etiologies of various derangements and common patterns suggestive of specific diagnoses.

item.title: Cardiac Auscultation (Abridged)
item.description: An abridged version of my 2 part video series on heart sounds and heart murmurs.

item.title: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT): Lesson 5 - Summary and Practice Cases
item.description: A summary of the first 4 videos in this series on PFT interpretation, as well as 5 practice cases which integrate PFTs with a clinical vignette and chest X-ray.

item.title: Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis
item.description:
A review of the pathogenesis, clinical manifestation, diagnosis, and treatment of this acute complication of cirrhosis.
This video is for educational purposes only, and is not intended to direct the care of any specific patient. No video can supersede the opinion of an experienced and licensed health care professional.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 10 - Self Assessment): Part 2
item.description:
Part 2 of 2 of a facilitated self-assessment on the interpretation of chest x-rays.
Sources for images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 10 - Self Assessment): Part 1
item.description:
A self-assessment of how much material was learned and retained from this course on interpreting chest x-rays, and how well it can be incorporated into the viewer's preexisting clinical knowledge.
Sources for images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: Cirrhosis - Physical Findings
item.description: A review of the physical exam findings of cirrhosis, including ascites, edema, jaundice, caput medusae, asterixis, hypotension, palmar errythema, gynecomastia, terry's nails, spider angiomas, and testicular atrophy.

item.title: EKG Textbook and Website Review
item.description:
A discussion of some recommended EKG/ECG textbooks and educational websites.
Books discussed: The Only EKG Book You'll Ever Need http://www.amazon.com/Only-Book-Youll-Ever-Need/dp/1451119054/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1409976639&sr=8-1&keywords=malcolm+thaler

ECG Pocket Brain https://www.kg-ekgpress.com/
Marriot's Practical Electrocardiography https://www.kg-ekgpress.com/

item.title: Update on Eric's Medical Lectures
item.description: A quick update on the state of Eric's Medical Lectures

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Myocardial Infarctions (Part 2 of 2)
item.description: A review of the EKG findings in MIs, including their morphological classification, a determination of their age, and localization to region of the heart and likely culprit vessel.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Myocardial Infarctions (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: A review of the EKG findings in MIs, including their morphological classification, a determination of their age, and localization to region of the heart and likely culprit vessel.

item.title: Hypertension - Treatment Thresholds and Lifestyle Modifications
item.description: A discussion of how high BP must be before starting anti-hypertensive therapy, and the 4 major non-pharmacologic treatments of hypertension (weight loss, low sodium diet, exercise, limiting alcohol intake)

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - QRST Changes
item.description: A summary of pathologic Q waves, R wave progression, ST elevation and depression, and T wave abnormalities.

item.title: The Medical H and P (Comparative Examples)
item.description: A comparison of a merely adequate vs. a great oral presentation of a medical H&P. (Sorry, there are a few minor typos in the annotations, which will hopefully be obvious when you encounter them.)

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Practicing Tachyarrhythmia Identification
item.description: 10 examples of tachyarrythmias, along with explanations as to how to identify them.

item.title: Hypertension - Antihypertensive Medications
item.description: A review of the classes, mechanisms, indications, and contraindications for antihypertensive meds, along with specific recommendations when starting therapy.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - How to Identify Any Tachyarrhythmia with 6 Easy Questions
item.description: An approach to the differential diagnosis of tachyarrhythmias based upon EKG characteristics.

item.title: Hypertension - An Introduction to High Blood Pressure
item.description: Covers the definition, risk factors and etiologies, and the physiologic mechanisms behind the development of hypertension.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Overview of Tachyarrhythmias
item.description: Mechanisms, etiologies, and EKG characteristics of sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, multifocal atrial tachycardia, supraventricular tachycardia, and ventricular tachycardia.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Mechanisms of Tachyarrhythmias
item.description: A description of the 3 major mechanisms of tachyarrhythmias: increased automaticity, reentry, and triggered activity.

item.title: Mastering EKGs - A Course Introduction
item.description: An introduction to a 30 video, complete course on EKG interpretation, which will provide viewers the knowledge necessary to go from an EKG novice to an expert.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 9 - Atelectasis, Lines, Tubes, Devices, and Surgeries)
item.description:
A summary of how to identify atelectasis (including lobar collapse), identify various lines, tubes, and devices (including proper placement, and complications), and identification of prosthetic heart valves.
Video includes the following images (among others):
Juxtaphrenic peak, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Gagandeep Singh
