item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - AV Block
item.description: A review of the EKG diagnosis of atrioventricular block, including discussion of the 3 different degrees of block, including the 3 different types of 2nd degree block and complete heart block. The etiologies, prognosis, and treatment of each form of block is reviewed as well.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 8 - Focal Lung Processes)
item.description:
A discussion of how to identify, localize, and describe pneumonia, as well as pulmonary nodules and lung cavities. Signs of a pulmonary embolism are reviewed as well.
Video includes the following images (among others):
RML pneumonia, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Roberto Schubert.
Lung abscess, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Abhijit Datir.
Sources for other images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - The 5 Cardinal Rules
item.description: Never trust the computer, use a systematic method, consider the clinical context with synthesizing findings, compare current EKG to prior, and EKG is just one more piece of imperfect data to incorporate into the differential diagnosis.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - A Systematic Approach
item.description: A summary of how a medical trainee should approach EKG / ECG interpretation, including rhythm assessment, evaluation of the QRS axis and morphology, and ST-T abnormalities

item.title: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT): Lesson 4 - DLCO
item.description: A description of how the DLCO (diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide) is measured, and how it is used in the diagnosis of various forms of lung disease.

item.title: Vasculitis - An Overview
item.description:
An overview of vasculitis, including common clinical features and classification.
(Dedicated to the wonderful Harold Ramis)

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 7 - Diffuse Lung Processes)
item.description:
An explanation of alveolar vs. interstitial opacities, including cardiogenic and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and the 3 types of interstitial patterns (reticular, nodular, and reticulonodular). Examples provided of air bronchograms, peribroncial cuffing, Kerley A and B lines, and cephalization. Etiologies of low lung volumes and hyperinflation are also discussed.
Video includes the following image (among others):
Cephalization, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Charlie Chia-Tsong Hsu.
Sources for other images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceras' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT): Lesson 3 - Lung Volumes
item.description: The methods of measuring lung volumes (e.g. helium dilution, nitrogen washout, body plethysmography), and a discussion of how the total lung capacity affects PFT interpretation, particularly the diagnosis of restrictive lung disease.

item.title: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT): Lesson 2 - Spirometry
item.description: A discussion of FEV1, FVC, FEV1/FVC ratio, and the flow volume loop, including how these are used in the diagnosis of various lung diseases, with a particular focus on the distinction between obstructive and restrictive lung disease. A summary of flow volume loop patterns in upper airway obstruction is covered as well.

item.title: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT): Lesson 1 - An Introduction
item.description: An introduction to the interpretation of pulmonary function tests. Covered in this first lesson are indications for PFTs, types of PFTs, and an overview of the subdivisions of lung volume.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 6 - Diaphragm and Pleura)
item.description:
A review of how to diagnose a pneumothorax, various forms of pleural effusion, other forms of pleural disease, and pneumoperitoneum. A differential diagnosis for each of these findings is discussed as well.
Video includes the following images (among others):
Right pleural effusion, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Roberto Schubert
Pleural plaques, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Jeremy Jones
Presumed mesothelioma, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Jeremy Jones
Pneumoperitoneum, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Henry Knipe
Chilaiditi's sign, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Hani Salam.
Sources for other images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 5 - Cardiac Silhouette and Mediastinum)
item.description:
A review of cardiomegaly, left atrial and right ventricular enlargement, mediastinal masses, and hilar enlargement.
Video includes the following images (among others):
Left atrial enlargement, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Alexandra Stanislavsky.
Pericardial effusion, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Frank Gaillard.
Multinodular goiter, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Hani Salam.
Sarcoidosis, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Christoph Berlinger.
Schwannoma, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally posted by Hani Salam.
Sources for other images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 4 - Airways, Bones, and Soft Tissues)
item.description:
An overview of how to assess the airways, bones, and soft tissues on chest X-ray, including the important etiologies of common radiographic abnormalities.
Video includes following images (among others):
Left atrial enlargement, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Alexendra Stanislavsky.
Cervical ribs, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, originally provided by Jeremy Jones.
Rib notching, downloaded from Radiopaedia.org, original uploader undetermined (image can no longer be located on site).
Sources for other images may include Wikimedia Commons, radiologypics.com, and Jose Caceres' wonderful radiology blog: Caceres Corner (http://blog.myesr.org/category/caceres-corner/)

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 3 - Assessing Technical Quality)
item.description:
A discussion of how to assess the technical quality of a chest x-ray, including assessment of rotation, adequacy of inspiration, and adequacy of exposure/penetration. The consequences for interpretation that each technical liability can lead to is also covered.
Sources for images include Wikimedia Commons and radiologypics.com.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 2 - A Systematic Method and Anatomy)
item.description: A description of a systematic method for examining a chest X-ray, and a review of the relevant thoracic anatomy.

item.title: How to Interpret a Chest X-Ray (Lesson 1 - An Introduction)
item.description: An introduction to the interpretation of chest X-rays, covering the basic principles of using X-rays in medical imaging, as well as the conventional X-ray views (i.e. PA, lateral, and AP).

item.title: Surface Tension and Surfactant (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 12)
item.description: A discussion of surface tension, with emphasis on the role surfactant has in reducing surface tension within the lungs, and the consequence this has for respiratory mechanics.

item.title: Insomnia (Common Cross-Cover Calls)
item.description: A review of how to handle calls for insomnia when cross-covering inpatient medicine. Contributing factors to the development of insomnia in the hospital are discussed, along with specific indications and contraindications for common sedatives.

item.title: Hyperkalemia
item.description: A review of the clinical manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic work-up, and treatment of hyperkalemia, including hypoaldosteronism.

item.title: Hypokalemia
item.description: The clinical manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic evaluation, and treatment of hypokalemia, including states of mineralocorticoid excess.

item.title: Hypernatremia - Examples
item.description: 2 worked examples of how to determine appropriate IV fluid and infusion rates in patients with hypernatremia.

item.title: Hypernatremia
item.description: A review of hypernatremia, including physiology, etiologies, diagnostic work-up, and treatment. Particular focus given to diabetes insipidus.

item.title: Hypertensive Emergency (Common Cross-Cover Calls)
item.description: An overview of how to approach calls regarding elevated blood pressure while cross-covering on inpatient medicine. The distinction between hypertensive emergency and urgency is covered, as well as some of the differences between various anti-hypertensives appropriate when treating acute hypertension.

item.title: Delirium (Common Cross-Cover Calls)
item.description: An brief overview of how to handle calls for altered mental status while cross-covering patients in the hospital.

item.title: The Medical H and P (Part 2 of 2)
item.description: An annotated example of an oral presentation of an internal medicine H&P, based on the principles discussed in part 1 of the 2 part video series.

item.title: The Medical H and P (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: An overview of the medical history and physical, including its format, organization, and content. A comparison between the oral presentation and written note is also included.

item.title: Hyponatremia
item.description: A review of hyponatremia, including symptoms, etiologies, diagnostic work-up, and treatment. Specific attention is given to the use of hypertonic saline, the osmotic demyelination syndrome (a.k.a. central pontine myelinolysis), as well as distinguishing SIADH from cerebral salt wasting.

item.title: Eric's Medical Lectures - Channel Trailer
item.description: A brief introduction to Eric's Medical Lectures

item.title: Sodium and Potassium Metabolism (Renin, Angiotensin, Aldosterone, and ADH)
item.description: A review of the normal physiology of sodium, potassium, and water. Major topics covered include the renin angiotensin aldosterone system, the hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis, ADH (antidiuretic hormone), and the natriuretic peptides.

item.title: Magnesium Disorders
item.description: A summary of normal magnesium homeostasis, and an overview of the manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic evaluation, and treatment of both hypomagnesemia and hypermagnesemia.

item.title: Reynolds Numbers and Turbulence (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 11)
item.description: A review of the meaning of turbulence, and calculation of the Reynolds number for fluid moving through a tube. Focus it given to the concept's relationship to the heart murmurs, as well as the theoretical benefits of breathing a helium/oxygen mixture called Heliox.

item.title: Viscosity and Poiseuille's Law (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 10)
item.description: A description of viscosity and Poiseuille's Law, which relates the pressure gradient along an enclosed conduit to the viscosity, length of conduit, radius of conduit, and fluid low. Several examples of its application in medicine are discussed, including rapid infusion of fluids, asthma attacks, hyperviscosity syndrome, and leukostasis.

item.title: Hypophosphatemia
item.description: A review of hypophosphatemia, including clinical manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic approach, and treatment. Specific topics of focus include refeeding syndrome, Fanconi syndrome, and the effect of hypophosphatemia on the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve.

item.title: Hyperphosphatemia
item.description: A review of hyperphosphatemia, including the clinical manifestation, etiologies, diagnostic approach, and treatment options. Specific topics included are Fleet Phospho Soda and phosphate binders (i.e. Phos-Lo, Renagel, etc...)

item.title: Hypocalcemia
item.description: A review of hypocalcemia, including its clinical manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic approach, and treatment. Major topics include vitamin d deficiency, hypoparathyroidism, and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

item.title: Hypercalcemia
item.description: A review of the clinical manifestations, etiologies, diagnostic approach, and treatment of hypercalcemia. Major included topics are hyperparathyroidism, hypercalcemia of malignancy, milk-alkali syndrome, and bisphosphonates.

item.title: Calcium and Phosphate Metabolism
item.description: A review of normal calcium and phosphate homeostasis, including discussion of vitamin D metabolism and the actions of PTH, as well as brief mention of the newly discovered role of FGF23.

item.title: How to Create a Differential Diagnosis (Part 3 of 3)
item.description: Part 3 of a 3 part video series on clinical reasoning, focusing on how to create a differential diagnoiss from a patient's presentation. Topics covered include determination of key features, problem representation, semantic qualifiers, and diagnostic frameworks,

item.title: How to Create a Differential Diagnosis (Part 2 of 3)
item.description: Part 2 of a 3 part video series on clinical reasoning, focusing on how to create a differential diagnoiss from a patient's presentation. Topics covered include determination of key features, problem representation, semantic qualifiers, and diagnostic frameworks,

item.title: How to Create a Differential Diagnosis (Part 1 of 3)
item.description: Part 1 of a 3 part video series on how to create a differential diagnosis from a patient's presentation. Covered topics include identifying the key features of a presentation, creating a problem representation, use of semantic qualifiers, and the components of a solid and practical differential diagnosis.

item.title: Channel Trailer
item.description: An introduction to my YouTube channel, which presents educational videos on a variety of medical topics, created for health care professionals in training.

item.title: Choose My Next Video Topic Follow Up
item.description: I discuss which topics suggested by viewers will be covered first in new videos to be posted over the upcoming months.

item.title: Archimedes' Principle and Buoyancy (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 2)
item.description: A review of Archimedes' Principle and the buoyant force, including 2 worked examples, and a brief description of how the principle of neutral buoyancy applies to the brain and cerebrospinal fluid.

item.title: Ohm's Law and Hemodynamics (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 9)
item.description: A description of how to apply Ohm's Law from E&M to understand hemodynamics, specifically the relationship between blood pressure, cardiac output, and systemic vascular resistance. I also briefly cover the different forms of shock.

item.title: The Bernoulli Equation - Medical Applications (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 8)
item.description: An overview of several medical applications of the Bernoulli Equation, including a description of the Venturi mask, and how echocardiography is used to estimate pulmonary artery pressure.

item.title: Choose My Next Video Topic
item.description: Here is your opportunity to choose topics for my videos. I'll wait at least 2 weeks before choosing the ideas that will be the most relevant to the greatest number of viewers, and be the most manageable in scope.

item.title: The Bernoulli Equation (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 7)
item.description: A brief description of the Bernoulli equation and Bernoulli's principle, with 2 examples, including one demonstrating the Venturi effect.

item.title: The Continuity Equation (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 6)
item.description: A simplified derivation and explanation of the continuity equation, along with 2 examples.

item.title: Pascal's Law (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 5)
item.description: A video reviewing Pascal's Law, including several classic examples including simple hydraulics.

item.title: Hydrostatic Pressure - Medical Applications (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 4)
item.description: A review of some of the uses of pressure measurements in medicine, with a focus on measuring the jugular venous pressure and bladder pressure.

item.title: Hydrostatic Pressure (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 3)
item.description: A description of hydrostatic pressure, along with the equation to calculate it, and an example.

item.title: Density and Specific Gravity (Fluid Mechanics - Lesson 1)
item.description: An overview of the meaning of density and specific gravity, along with their calculations and some example problems. The relevance of specific gravity in analyzing urine is also discussed.

item.title: Fluid Mechanics in Medicine - An Introduction
item.description: An introduction to a 2 hr course on basic fluid mechanics, with an emphasis on common medical applications. For those studying to get into medical school, the course will cover about half of MCAT 2015 Foundational Concept 4b ("Importance of fluids for the circulation of blood, gas movement, and gas exchange").

item.title: Final Topics (Antibiotics- Lecture 10)
item.description: A few final topics are discussed in this last lecture on antibiotics, including treatment duration, pre-procedure prophylaxis, and antibiotic lock therapy.

item.title: Antibiotic Resistance (Antibiotics - Lecture 9)
item.description: A lecture covering mechanisms of antibiotic resistance, principles behind susceptibility testing including understanding the MIC, interpretation of antibiotic susceptibility reports, and the factors contributing to increasing antibiotic resistance worldwide.

item.title: Pathologic Complications (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 11)
item.description: A lecture covering the consequences of endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation, focusing on auto-PEEP, patient ventilator dyssynchrony, and ventilator associated pneumonia.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - EKG Leads
item.description: A lecture on EKG / ECG leads, include the basic principles behind how they work, their spatial orientation, and their anatomical correlations, along with the proper placement of EKG electrodes. Best viewed in 1080p.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Waveforms, Segments, and Intervals
item.description: A lecture on the identification and significance of EKG / ECG waveforms, segments, and intervals. Viewing in 1080p recommended.

item.title: Important Side Effects and Toxicities (Antibiotics - Lecture 8)
item.description: A lecture covering the major side effects of antibiotics, including allergic reactions, diarrhea, C.diff colitis, QT prolongation, and interactions with warfarin. It also includes discussion of cross reactivity between penicillins and cephalosporins, as well as how to use serum drug levels to titrate vancomycin and aminoglycosides.

item.title: Physiologic Consequences (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 10)
item.description: A lecture on the physiologic consequences of positive pressure ventilation.

item.title: EKG and Heart Murmur Review - Part 2
item.description: Part 2 of a case-based review of introductory EKG interpretation and cardiac auscultation. These cases are slightly more challenging than those in part 1. I highly recommend viewing in 1080p.

item.title: EKG and Heart Murmur Review - Part 1
item.description:
A review of basic EKG interpretation and cardiac auscultation, using actual clinical cases to demonstrate connections between patient symptoms, EKG findings, and abnormalities of auscultation. I recommend first viewing my videos on "Heart Murmurs", "Heart Sounds", "Intro to EKG: Rate and Axis", and "Intro to EKG: Chamber Enlargement", as this review will rely heavily on information present during those lectures.
I highly recommend watching in 1080p.

item.title: Antibiotics for Atypical Infections (Antibiotics - Lecture 7)
item.description: A lecture on the antibiotics used for treating infections caused be atypical bacteria - specifically Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Chlamydophila, Rickettsia, and Legionella. Specific antibiotics covered include azithromycin, doxycycline, quinolones, and chloramphenicol.

item.title: Antibiotics for Anaerobic Infections (Antibiotics - Lecture 6)
item.description: A summary of antibiotics used to fight infections caused by anaerobic infections (e.g. clindamycin, metronidazole, broad-spectrum beta lactams, and quinolones).

item.title: Antibiotics for Gram Negative Infections (Antibiotics - Lecture 5)
item.description: A summary of antibiotics used to fight infections caused by gram negative organisms, with a focus on Pseudomonas, ESBL, Acinetobacter, and Stenotrophomonas.

item.title: Antibiotics for Gram Positive Infections (Antibiotics - Lecture 4)
item.description: A summary of antibiotics used to fight infections caused by gram positive organisms, with a focus on MRSA (methicillin resistant staph aureus) and VRE (vancomycin resistant enterococcus).

item.title: Mechanisms and Classification of Antibiotics (Antibiotics - Lecture 3)
item.description: A summary of the mechanisms and classification of antibiotics, with particular focus on penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, quinolones, and aminoglycosides. A brief description of the discovery of penicillin is also reviewed.

item.title: Bacterial Etiologies of Common Infections (Antibiotics - Lecture 2)
item.description:
A summary of the role and composition of normal flora, the typical bacterial pathogens causing several common infectious diseases, diagnosis of UTI, and interpretation as to whether a positive blood culture represents true infection or contamination.
Bonus points to anyone who can identify the mystery portrait.

item.title: Classification of Bacteria (Antibiotics - Lecture 1)
item.description: The opening video on a course on antibiotics, focusing on how morphology, gram stain, and other tests of bacteria can be used to create a clinically useful classification scheme.

item.title: Antibiotics - A Course Introduction
item.description: A brief introduction to a 10 lecture course on antibiotics, focusing on those used in the treatment of acute bacterial diseases.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Bundle Branch Blocks
item.description: A lecture on intraventricular conduction delays, including bundle branch blocks (complete and incomplete), fascicular blocks, and non-specific intraventricular conduction delay. Major etiologies of these diagnoses are reviewed as well. I highly recommend watching it in full screen mode in 1080p.

item.title: Inpatient Diabetes Management
item.description:
A summary of the inpatient management of diabetes. Topics include the sliding scale, basal bolus regimens, adjusting insulin when NPO, adjusting insulin for persistent hyperglycemia, and the consistent carb diet.
Information here is provided for educational purposes only, and is not intended to substitute for the opinion of an experienced and licensed health care professional.
This work is made available under the terms of the Creative Commons, Attribution-NonCommerical-NoDerivs 3.0 Unported License. It may be reproduced and distributed provided that accurate attribution remains, the work is not altered in any way, and it is not used for commercial purposes. For details, please refer to: creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/deed.en_US.

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Rate and Axis
item.description:
How to determine heart rate and QRS axis on EKG / ECG. Viewing in 1080p is highly recommended.
This material is made available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 Unported License

item.title: Intro to EKG Interpretation - Chamber Enlargement
item.description:
A video on the identification of atrial enlargement and ventricular hypertrophy on EKG. Viewing in 1080p is highly recommended (click on the gear icon just below the lower right corner of the video).
This material is made available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 Unported License.

item.title: Heart Murmurs
item.description:
A lecture on the identification and characterization of heart murmurs.
Changes for this revised version include: - Video recompiled in high definition and in wide screen format. - Narration rerecorded. - Audio clips of murmurs remastered. - Copyrighted images used under fair use principles replaced with original images or those in public domain. - Soundtrack replaced with original arrangement and rendering. - Copyright notice added.
Please leave comments/feedback/questions.

item.title: Using the ABG to Create a Unified Model of Human Pathophysiology (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 20)
item.description: The final lecture in a course on the interpretation of ABGs, in which all of the previously presented information is synthesized into a global approach to a wide variety of pathophysiologic problems.

item.title: Dyshemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin and Carbon Monoxide Poisoning (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 19)
item.description: A discussion of the pathophysiology and etiology of methemoglobinemia and carbon monoxide poisoning, including a review of the structure and function of hemoglobin, and the basic principles behind pulse oximetry and co-oximetry.

item.title: Hypoxia and Hypoxemia: Mechanisms and Etiologies (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 18)
item.description: A review of the mechanisms and etiologies of hypoxemia, focusing on impaired diffusion, ventilation/perfusion mismatch, and shunting.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Pearls and Pitfalls of Acid-Base Analysis (Lesson 14)
item.description: Some pearls and pitfalls of ABG interpretation. Topics covered include whether a VBG can substitute for an ABG, whether one should use the measure bicarb or the calculated bicarb, the effect of temperature on the ABG, and how to diagnose acute on chronic respiratory disorders.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: A Grand Overview of Acid-Base Analysis (Lesson 13)
item.description: This lecture presents a synthesis of the traditional approach to acid-base analysis from an ABG, including a master algorithm. The major points of lectures 1-12 from the course will be summarized, followed by four advanced examples in which the master algorithm is used to span the distance between an ABG and a final diagnosis.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Alternative Approaches to Acid Base Analysis (Lesson 15)
item.description: A lecture on the base excess and Stewart approaches to acid-base balance, including qualitative and quantitative comparisons to the traditional approach.

item.title: Elevated Anion Gap Metabolic Acidoses - Abridged (Understanding ABGs - Lecture 8)
item.description: An abridged version of a lecture on the differential diagnosis and diagnostic work-up of an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis

item.title: Respiratory Alkalosis (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 12)
item.description: A lecture on the differential diagnosis of respiratory alkaloses

item.title: Respiratory Acidosis (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 11)
item.description: A lecture on the differential diagnosis of respiratory acidosis, also covering the physiology of the control of ventilation.

item.title: The Effect of High Altitude on Oxygenation (ABG Interpretation - Supplemental Video)
item.description: A lecture on the effect that high altitude has on interpreting and understanding ABGs.

item.title: Derivation of the Alveolar Ventilation and Alveolar Gas Equations (ABG Interpretaion: Supp. Video)
item.description: A review of the derivation of the alveolar ventilation and alveolar gas equations, which largely rely on Dalton's Law

item.title: The Effect of Supplemental Oxygen (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 17)
item.description: A lecture on the effect of supplemental oxygen on how to use the ABG to understand a patient's oxygenation status. Included is a summary of various options of oxygen delivery, including a discussion of nasal cannula and various types of face masks including the Venturi mask.

item.title: The A-a Gradient (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 16)
item.description: A lecture on the ways in which the ABG can be used to assess oxygenation, focusing on the alveolar gas equation and the A-a gradient. Several examples of ABG interpretation are included.

item.title: Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 9)
item.description: A lecture on the differential diagnosis of a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, focusing on renal tubular acidosis, but also covering diarrhea, saline infusion, hyperkalemia, kidney failure, and ureteral diversion

item.title: Examples of mitral stenosis murmurs
item.description: An explanation of the mitral stenosis murmurs from the heart murmur lecture (in response to a question posted in the comments).

item.title: Metabolic Alkalosis (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 10)
item.description: A lecture on the differential diagnosis of a metabolic alkalosis, focusing on contraction alkalosis, loop and thiazide diuretics, mineralocorticoid excess, and hypokalemia. Also covered are Barrter, Gitelman, and Liddle syndromes, and licorice toxicity.

item.title: Elevated Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 8)
item.description:
A review of the differential diagnosis of an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, focusing predominantly on lactic acid, ketoacids, and toxic alcohols (i.e. methanol, ethylene glycol, and propylene glycol). Also includes discussion of renal failure, oxoproline, toluene, and paraldeyhyde.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Introduction and Course Overview (Lesson 1)
item.description:
An overview of a 20 video course on understanding the arterial blood gas (ABG), followed by a brief introduction to the topic.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: Heart Sounds
item.description:
A lecture on the recognition and physiology of both normal and abnormal heart sounds with numerous audio examples. Covered sounds include S1, S2, S3, S4, clicks, an opening snap and pericardial knock. The scientific evidence for the diagnostic utility of abnormal sounds is also discussed. For the most accurate reproduction of the heart sounds, I recommend listening with headphones instead of standard external computer speakers.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Mixed Acid-Base Disorders with Normal pH (Lesson 7)
item.description: Discussion of how to diagnose complex acid-base disorders in which the overall pH is normal. Multiple examples are included and worked out in detail.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: The Delta Ratio and Triple Disorders (Lesson 6)
item.description: How to use the delta ratio (a.k.a. the "delta-delta") and the delta gap to diagnose mixed metabolic disorders, including triple acid-base disorders

item.title: ABG Interpretation: The Anion Gap (Lesson 5)
item.description: A discussion of the anion gap, including its calculation and its use in categorizing metabolic acidoses, including multiple examples of acid-base interpretation.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Compensation and Mixed Disorders (Lesson 4)
item.description: A lecture discussing the phenomenon of physiologic compensation for derangements of acid-base balance, and how to use an understanding of compensation to identify the presence of mixed acid-base disorders.

item.title: ABG Interpretation: Simple Acid-Base Disorders (Lesson 3)
item.description:
Lecture that discusses the differences between acidemia and acidosis, and alkalemia and alkalosis, and then moves on to demonstrate how to diagnosis simple acid-base disorders from the ABG.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: Normal Acid-Base Regulation (ABG Interpretation - Lesson 2)
item.description:
A lecture on the physiology of normal acid-base regulation, including a discussion of the bicarbonate buffering system, the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, and elimination of acid from the body via the lungs and kidneys.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: Normal Gas Exchange (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 4)
item.description: A lecture on the exchange of carbon dioxide and oxygen in the lungs, including discussion of the alveolar ventilation equation, alveolar gas equation, and the alveolar-arterial gradient.

item.title: Lung Protective Ventilation (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 9)
item.description: A lecture on lung protective ventilation, including a discussion of the various forms of ventilator-associated lung injury, as well as permissive hypercapnia and open lung ventilation.

item.title: Heart Murmur Example 1 Explained
item.description: A brief explanation of the 1st practice example from the heart murmur lecture.

item.title: Ventilator Options (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 8)
item.description: A lecture on how to set basic ventilator options (e.g. tidal volume, rate, PEEP, etc...).

item.title: Ventilator Modes (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 7)
item.description:
A lecture on the various modes of mechanical ventilation, focusing on assist control, SIMV, pressure control ventilation (PCV), and pressure support ventilation (PSV)
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: Monitoring Lung Mechanics (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 3)
item.description: A lecture on how to use peak pressure and plateau pressure to monitor for changes in airway resistance and lung compliance.

item.title: Normal Lung Mechanics (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 2)
item.description:
A lecture on lung mechanics, focusing on descriptions of different lung volumes, dead space, airway resistance and lung compliance.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: An Introduction to Mechanical Ventilation (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 1)
item.description:
A lecture on the indications for mechanical ventilation, as well as the physiologic differences between negative and positive pressure ventilation.
Use of the VA and Stanford name/logos is only to indicate my academic affiliation, and neither implies endorsement nor ownership of the included material.

item.title: Monitoring Gas Exchange (Mechanical Ventilation - Lecture 5)
item.description:
A lecture on how to monitor gas exchange in the mechanically ventilated patient, focusing on the ABG, pulse oximetry, and capnography.
